image.altText: Elise Archer rests her head on her hand in parliament.

props.synopsis: Former Tasmanian Liberal MP Elise Archer says she's "reconsidering" quitting state parliament and might sit as an Independent, which an electoral analyst says could trigger an early state election.

title.children: Elise Archer 'reconsidering' quitting parliament, early election risk for Tasmanian Liberals

image.altText: An aerial photo of a small, busy town at sunset with a hotel in the foreground and cars parked along the main street.

props.synopsis: Converted airports, refurbished nursing homes, caravans, sheds and school camps aren't considered suitable housing options. But they're all inÂ the mix as workers struggle to find a place to live near their workplace that they can afford.

title.children: This seaside town is so popular that employers are turning an aged care home into accommodation for their staff

image.altText: A bearded man smiles slightly in front of lake and reeds of grass at sunset

props.synopsis: Seaweed, cows and cutting-edge science: This is how Sam Elsom swapped fashion for farming to spearhead a revolutionary climate change solution. But he's facing a major obstacle.

title.children: How a humble seaweed inspired Sam to build an innovative solution to climate change

image.altText: Rebecca Jeffcoat wearing goggles and sub-zero protective clothing in Antarctic landscape.

props.synopsis: It's one of the most challenging work environments on the planet. But with hundreds of applicants, the process of selecting the best candidate takes eight months and resembles a reality TV contest.

title.children: Reckon you can handle a year in Antarctica as a station leader? This is what it takes to pass the test

image.altText: Jesse Arthars of the Brisbane Broncos sits against a goalpost after the NRL grand final.

props.synopsis: Coming so close to winning the NRL premiership and missing out has proven hard to overcome for some sides, and the most brutal but effective teacher for others. Now we will see how the Broncos handle it, writes Jon Healy.

title.children: The Broncos are young, but one key piece is on a different timeline and the clock is ticking after the grand final

image.altText: A man in glasses holds his hand out as he speaks into microphone.

props.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Investigation launched after US congressman sets off fire alarm, NSW govt faces renewed calls to bring in pill-testing. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Half of the country can officially vote early in the Voice to Parliament referendum today. Early voting begins on Monday October 2 for the following states and territories: Northern Territory Tasmania Victoria Western Australia You can read more on where to vote early and who is eligible in the link below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Early referendum voting starts today for half of Australia

featuredLink.title: Early referendum voting starts today in half the country. Here's where to vote early and who's eligible

children.content: Half of the country can officially vote early in the Voice to Parliament referendum today.
Early voting begins on Monday October 2 for the following states and territories:
Northern Territory
Tasmania
Victoria
Western Australia
You can read more on where to vote early and who is eligible in the link below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: An investigation has been launched after a congressman in the US House of Representatives triggered a fire alarm as his party was trying to delay a crucial funding vote on the weekend. Democrat Jamaal Bowman says it was an accident. His party wanted more time to decide whether to support it and his opponents have accused him of trying to disrupt the vote. The bill to avoid a federal government shutdown ultimately passed, keeping the government open for another 45 days.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Investigation launched after a  US congressman sets off fire alarm

children.content: An investigation has been launched after a congressman in the
US House of Representatives
triggered a fire alarm as his party was trying to delay a crucial funding vote on the weekend.
Democrat Jamaal Bowman
says it was an accident.
His party wanted more time to decide whether to support it and his opponents have accused him of trying to disrupt the vote.
The bill to avoid a
federal government shutdown
ultimately passed, keeping the government open for another 45 days.

props.alt: A man stands with a microphone and his hand out.

children.content: Democrat Jamaal Bowman says setting off the  fire alarm was an accident.
(Reuters: Andrew Kelly)

image.altText: Catastrophic fire warning

props.synopsis: For some people, the coming warmer months are not a celebration. They are something to fear, or feel sad about, writes Tara Crandon.

title.children: Not everyone is excited about the warmer months. For some, summer can trigger anxiety and grief

image.altText: A student at Yipirinya School wiping his eye.

props.synopsis: For decades, an eye disease known as trachoma was stealing the sight of Indigenous Australians. Now, the disease is on its way to being eradicated.

title.children: How this little-known eye infection is still stealing sight in parts of Australia

image.altText: Red smoke billows across the horizon.

props.synopsis: Crews are working to contain multiple fires in Victoria's eastÂ as forecastÂ winds approach, with confirmation at least one house and about 5,000 hectares have burnt in the spring blazes.

title.children: One home lost, thousands of hectares burnt as early spring fires 'shock' Victorian communities

image.altText: A manÂ looks at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: Australian stocks are poised to start the final quarter of this year lower, while the Reserve Bank is almost universally tipped to hold interest rates steady in tomorrow's board meeting.Â Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX to drop ahead of RBA interest rate decision, Wall Street mixed

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Data showed the personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index, excluding the volatile food and energy components, increased 3.9 per cent on an annual basis for August, the first time in over two years it had fallen below 4 per cent. The Fed tracks the PCE price indexes for its 2 per cent inflation target. The data revealed a âbetter than expected but still elevated inflation picture,â said Eric Freedman, chief investment officer at US Bank Asset Management. The highly anticipated PCE data followed the recent hawkish long-term outlook for rates from the US Federal Reserve, which has rattled stocks as benchmark Treasury yields climbed to 16-year highs. âEquity investors are finally waking up to the Fed and the Fed comments that it is going to be higher for longer, and there is an alternative to stocks,â said Paul Nolte, senior wealth advisor and market strategist for Murphy & Sylvest Wealth Management.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US inflation subsides

children.content: Data showed the personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index, excluding the volatile food and energy components, increased 3.9 per cent on an annual basis for August, the first time in over two years it had fallen below 4 per cent.
The Fed tracks the PCE price indexes for its 2 per cent inflation target.
The data revealed a âbetter than expected but still elevated inflation picture,â said Eric Freedman, chief investment officer at US Bank Asset Management.
The highly anticipated PCE data followed the recent hawkish long-term outlook for rates from the US Federal Reserve, which has rattled stocks as benchmark Treasury yields climbed to 16-year highs.

âEquity investors are finally waking up to the Fed and the Fed comments that it is going to be higher for longer, and there is an alternative to stocks,â said Paul Nolte, senior wealth advisor and market strategist for Murphy
Sylvest Wealth Management.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning and welcome to Monday's markets live blog, where we'll bring you the latest price action and news on the ASX and beyond. And it looks like it could be a negative start, with ASX futures lower. It follows a mixed session on Wall Street last Friday. The S & P 500 and Nasdaq posted their biggest monthly percentage drops of the year, while all three major indexes had their first quarterly declines in 2023.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX to slide
